awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Data-Driven Modeling and Analyses of Extreme Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
Rogue (freak) waves are rare events but they pose one of the greatest maritime risks. This Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) award would be used to develop a unified, data-driven framework and tools to advance the analysis and prediction of oceanic freak waves. The results of the research would provide key information for risk-based design of civil engineering and marine systems such as offshore platforms, wind turbines, and ships. The framework and tools would also benefit fundamental research on other complex systems that generate large amounts of data that must be processed-- ranging from manufacturing processes to disaster planning and response. The researchers' work on identifying signatures of rare events within big data sets could advance fundamental research in a variety of areas from medical diagnostics to airport security and the development of advanced materials. Collaborations with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the US Navy will help to ensure that the work will be used to enhance weather forecasting and safety on the seas. The new framework is to be incorporated into a software package, which is used by NOAA, and is to be made available to researchers, students, and the public. Students will participate in the research and the results will be integrated into course materials and outreach activities for students in the University of Maryland, the US Naval Academy, and Women in Engineering. The researchers will also provide art-in-science displays on extreme wave phenomena for K-12 students. 
 
This research will be used to integrate statistical learning, signal processing, and Koopman operator theory to develop software tools and processes that can be configured to identify energy localizations across a variety of domains--including ocean waves-- to provide a prediction capability.   As rare events, there are few measurements of rogue waves but there is a wealth of information on storms, other atmospheric events and wave behavior. An interdisciplinary team will integrate existing NOAA databases, General-Purpose Graphics Processing Units (GPGPU) computing, and the application of machine learning.   The investigators will advance our understanding of how to use parallel processing of large-scale computations done by combining the processing power of GPUs and Central Processing Units (CPUs).  This enhanced understanding will advance fundamental research in dynamical systems by enabling more effective use of a suite of simulation and signal processing tools, such as wavelets, Fast Fourier Transforms, and Monte Carlo simulations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rogue waves in the ocean are large amplitude waves, which are often described as rare events. However, they are one of the most dangerous maritime events, which can cause severe damage to ships and offshore structures and people on board them. While rogue wave forecasts would be helpful to mitigate the risk of a rogue wave encounter, there is no accepted methodology for rogue wave forecasting. Thus, there is a recognized need in the weather service community to develop the foundations for extreme wave climatology. To address the development of this foundation, physics-based and data-driven computational approaches have been employed. The methods and approaches developed in this work are applicable for the development of a rogue wave forecasting system based on buoy data.

 

A multi-year effort has been pursued by a team of researchers from the University of Maryland. This group had three faculty members, one each from Atmospheric and Oceanic Science (AOSC), Computer Science, and Mechanical Engineering. Two of these faculty members are also members of the Applied Mathematics and Scientific Computation Program. Multiple graduate students and one post-doctoral researcher were also a part of the team. Through the computational studies, the researchers have gained insights into the role of physical mechanisms such as the modulational instability mechanism underlying rapid wave formations and developed a combination of physics-based and data-driven approaches and purely data-driven approaches for rogue wave forecasting. The team has also advanced the Local Ensemble Transform Kalman Filter (LETKF) based methodology for use in the WAVEWATCH-III wave model of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). As the current NOAA wave forecast system does not have explicit data assimilation, the LETKF advancement should help with NOAA’s United Forecast System. The team has developed different algorithms to aid wave forecasting. Machine learning elements from the work have been featured in a graduate course on nonlinear oscillations. Through the inter-disciplinary research, exceptional learning opportunities have been provided for multiple graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher. Different simulations and visualizations have been featured in annual exhibits to visitors from government laboratories, academia, and local schools to stimulate interest in engineering and sciences.

 

Three graduate students from Mechanical Engineering, one graduate student from Applied Mathematics, three graduate students from Computer Science, and one post-doctoral researcher have directly benefited from the research efforts. One of the graduate students from Mechanical Engineering received a M.S. degree and has joined industry, while one of the other graduate students from Mechanical Engineering completed her doctoral studies and assumed a post-doctoral position. The third student from Mechanical Engineering is currently a doctoral candidate who is set to graduate in 2025. The Applied Mathematics graduate student is expected to complete his doctoral studies in 2025 and pursue a research career. One of the Computer Science doctoral students has taken up a job in industry, after graduation. The other two students from Computer Science are continuing their graduate studies. The post-doctoral researcher will start in a tenure-track faculty position in January 2025.
